entry.title: DjangoCon 2013 Pictures
entry.summary:
The main purpose of being in Chicago from August 31 through Sept 9 was for one of my favorite conferences, DjangoCon 2013. Here are some pictures from speakers and a few views of the city. Many more pictures of Chicago coming soon.

Some of the DjangoCon schwag, including the new t-shirt design, as well as the conference program and attendee badge with lanyard.

Jacob Kaplan-Moss, one of the original developers of Django and now Director of Security at Heroku, speaking about doing security right and making it part of everyone's development process.

Josie Keller, one of the founders of GeekChic, speaking about giving women the tools they need to become active participants in the technology community.

Ken Cochrane of dotCloud speaking about the new hotness that is Docker.

Ben Lopatin, one of the founders of Wellfire Interactive speaking about Django and Search.

Matt Makai (hey, that's me!) of Excella Consulting speaking (preaching?) about using Django with third party services.

Matt Robenolt of Disqus speaking about HTTP tricks for scaling Django.

Russell Keith-Magee, Django core developer speaking about integrating web systems that weren't meant to be integrated. This talk was awesome because as a developer who's done some enterprise-y work in the past these are exactly the challenges you have to overcome that we take for granted as solved problems in most tech startup environments.

Nathan Duthoit of Wave speaking about database schema migrations.

Quick capture of the gold sponsors for DjangoCon, including our firm, Excella Consulting.

Dusk in Chicago on the final evening of the main DjangoCon schedule.

If you liked these pictures you should check out my photos from walking around Wicker Park and my first batch of photos from Chicago during my road trip.

entry.title: Chicago Wicker Park Pictures
entry.summary:
I flew in to Chicago ahead of DjangoCon 2013's tutorials and speaker dinner on Monday night. Here are some pictures from walking around and having lunch in Chicago's Wicker Park neighborhood.

Street sign at the intersection of Wicker Park Street and Monroe Street right outside the park.

A fountain in Wicker Park.

Greenery in Wicker Park.

Awesome street graffiti in the Wicker Park neighborhood.

Interesting street art in Wicker Park neighborhood at a dog park.

Interesting building I saw while walking around.

More of the buildings in the Wicker Park neighborhood.

Francesca's Forno Restaurant in Wicker Park.

Awesome barcade, Emporium Arcade Bar, in Wicker Park.

Arcade games lined at at Emporium Arcade Bar.

More photos from DjangoCon and my ten days in Chicago coming soon.

If you liked these pictures you should check out my first batch of photos from Chicago.

entry.title: Central Park NYC Pictures
entry.summary:
The last stop on my road trip was New York City. New York is a big enough place that although I grew up west of the city in Morristown, New Jersey, I never really felt I knew the area well. Pictures in this blog post are all related to Central Park.

Welcome to Central Park sign and a map of the extensive area.

One entrance to Central Park around 90th Street and 5th Avenue from the Upper East Side.

NYC skyline view from the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir.

Another view of the NYC skyline from the Jacqueline Onassis Reservoir.

Central Park near the Upper West Side.

A beautiful morning in Central Park. Upper West Side buildings towering above the trees.

Buildings on the Upper West Side.

Garbage piling up on a bench on the Upper West Side. NYC isn't just rainbows and unicorns.

A fountain in Central Park.

Walkway around the fountain.

Upper East Side view from Central Park.

Laying out at the Central Park softball fields with the Upper West Side in the (blurry) background.

If you liked these pictures you should check out my photos from Chicago and Memphis.

entry.title: Detroit Pictures
entry.summary:
I spent a few quick days in Detroit catching up on work between my time in Chicago and Buffalo. Most of my time was spent downtown near the Renaissance Center where I stayed but I also checked out Royal Oak a little ways north of downtown.

Statue of Cadillac, founder of Detroit.

Artwork in a park on the river looking up at the buildings downtown.

A view of downtown Detroit with Tigers stadium in the middle.

Another view of downtown Detroit but to the other side.

Found a cool hole-in-the-wall spot for lunch, Jacoby's.

Looking up at the Renaissance Center which houses GM's headquarters.

Looking out from the Renaissance Center to the river that separates Detroit from Canada.

Canada on the left, Detroit on the right.

Closer view of buildings in downtown Detroit.

Memorial for fallen World War II soldiers in Royal Oak, Michigan.

If you liked these pictures you should check out my Chicago, Illinois photos and Seattle city pictures.

entry.title: Chicago Pictures
entry.summary:
Chicago is an overwhelmingly large city upon first arrival, especially after hanging out in Des Moines, Omaha, and Madison for a couple of weeks. It's beautiful here though as these pictures (and ones I'll post as I continue to explore Chicago) show.

A view of the Chicago skyline taken from Navy Pier.

Street level looking up while in downtown.

Contrasting old and new buildings.

More contrast between old and new.

Foundations at Millenium Park.

Navy pier.

Close up view of a bridge connecting North Lake Shore Drive over the Chicago River.

If you liked these pictures you should check out my photos from Portland, Oregon.

entry.title: Colorado Hiking Pictures
entry.summary:
Hiking in Colorado was amazing - and tiring. It's tough on your lungs to go from about 5,000 feet elevation to 12,000+ feet within a 40 minute drive, then climb up a steep hill to go even higher. Still this trip was well worth the effort due to the amazing scenery at that level. Once again the pictures don't do it justice compared to being there in person but they still turned out reasonably well.

Me next to the Loveland Pass sign.

Loose rocks on the edge of looking down.

You can reach out and touch the clouds as you climb up Loveland Pass.

Snow capped mountains everywhere... in late June.

Audrey! Giving me a tour of her state Colorado after moving out from Virginia.

Me kneeling in front of the snow capped mountains in the distance.

The long winding road out of Loveland Pass.

Another winding road shot.

Only tiny vegetation like flowers live this far up the mountain.

A lake on the way back to Boulder from Loveland Pass.

"Classic" behind the S2000 shot while driving from Boulder to Golden, Colorado.

If you liked this post you should also check out my Moab photos and Seattle hiking pictures.

entry.title: Wyoming Photograpy
entry.summary:
Buffalo, Wyoming is one of my stops to hang out for a few days on the long trek from Seattle to Boulder. Luckily the weather has been clear here so I could snap these great pictures. The photos are from a combination of driving through the mountains and walking around and Buffalo.

Driving through Wyoming.

Mountains in Wyoming. I'm about to go over them.

Oblig "from the car" picture.

Small town in Wyoming I drove through.

Another shot of the town.

Scenery on the way to the mountains.

Abandoned buildings that must have been used somehow during the mining process back in the day.

View from Big Horn National Park almost 10,000 feet up. This picture sadly does not do it justice. You absolutely have to see it in person. This actually beat the scenery on the Pacific Coast Highway for me.

Another view from almost 10,000 feet up.

Clear blue sky.

Snow near the top. There are higher peaks to this mountain range but this was the one route 14 took me over.

Sign by the road for Big Horn Basin.

About 9,000 feet up on the other side of the mountain.

The Occidental Hotel, where I stayed for a few nights in Buffalo, Wyoming.

Nice stuffed head. This hotel is basically a museum for ecclectic historic items.

Creek outside the hotel in Buffalo, WY.

Statues in downtown Buffalo, WY.

Numerous empty old buildings line downtown.

Buffalo, Wyoming has a blacksmith. Buffalo: 1, Washington, D.C.: 0.

So this is Crazy Woman Square...

War Memorial for fallen soldiers in Buffalo, WY.

Awesome statue!

Another view of the statue.

The Virginian Restaraunt sign. Everyone loves Virginia, even in Wyoming.

If you liked this post you should check out my pictures from Los Alamos and Moab.

entry.title: Montana Pictures
entry.summary:
I spent a few days over the second weekend in June in both Missoula and Hamilton in Montana. I also stopped in Bozeman for lunch on the way to Wyoming. Montana is a beautiful state as I tried to capture in the pictures below.

M for Missoula. Every city in Montana had one of these from what I could tell.

Sign for downtown Missoula.

A view of the Clark Fork River that separates two sides of Missoula.

A view of the Clark Fork River from the Orange Street Bridge.

Sign on one end of the Orange Street Bridge.

Riverside Cafe in Missoula, Montana. Nice view from the patio.

Beautiful day in Missoula.

The amazing trail system in Missoula was perfect for walking, running, and biking. Seriously every city should put this much effort into making it easy for people to get around by means other than a car.

View of the mountains from one of the trails in Missoula.

World War I monument in Missoula.

View of the mountains from Hamilton, Montana.

An old Carnegie-endowed library in Bozeman, Montana.

Sign in front of the Carnegie library in Bozeman, Montana.

The Crystal Bar sign in downtown Bozeman, Montana.

If you liked these pictures, you should check out the photos from Moab, Utah and Portland, Oregon.

entry.title: Seattle City Pictures
entry.summary:
These are the best pictures I took from my time in downtown Seattle. It's a beautiful city and fortunately I had amazing weather during most of my time in town (the clouds in this first picture are the exception).

The Seattle Space Needle reflected against the Science Fiction museum.

The Space Needle again, this time on a beautiful day.

Looking up at the buildings in downtown Seattle.

Reflection in the window of a greenhouse downtown.

Wexley School for Girls. Great artwork on the side of the building.

The Fremont Troll.

I just thought this was funny...

Inscription in a Lower Queen Anne building.

Park on the water.

Rocks on the shore further up the way at the park.

People sailing out on a clear day.

Leaning and staring. Kinda artsy.

If you liked this post you should also check out my Seattle hiking pictures and photos from Portland, Oregon.

entry.title: Seattle Hiking Pictures
entry.summary:
I went hiking with a friend in Seattle on a beautiful clear day. Here are a few pictures from that trip about 30 miles East of the city. There are also a few pictures of the sun setting over the Pacific Ocean at the end of the day.

Looking up at the mountain peak at the start of the hike.

Making our way through the forest to the top.

Not a bad view from the top...

Another great view from a slightly different spot at the top.

One more great shot from the top.

Sunset in Seattle.

End of the day on the West Coast.

If you liked this post you should also check out my photos from The University of Washington and Portland, Oregon.

entry.title: University of Washington Pictures
entry.summary:
While in Seattle I luckily had a University of Washington alum show me around their campus. UW is a beautiful place and the school has one of the top computer science programs in the country.

The University of Washington logo statue at the entrance of their campus.

There's no uniform architecture for buildings on campus but every one is intricately detailed in different ways.

UW's computer science building. Donations from Microsoft founders at work.

A shaded grove next to UW's computer science building.

A closer look at the columns in the grove.

A plaque and looking up towards one of the main parts of the UW campus.

If you liked these pictures, you should check out the photos from Portland, Oregon and the Computer History Museum in Mountain View, California.

entry.title: Portland, Oregon Pictures
entry.summary:
Portland, Oregon was my seventeenth city during my travels. I cut back on my meetings substantially so I could write the initial text for my book. Portland has a great tech scene. It'll be a good spot to check it out again in the future.

Portland, Oregon sign from the Burnside Bridge.

View of the Portland skyline during the usual weather.

Downtown Portland from Buckman Neighborhood on the East side.

Curious tofu company sign that caught my eye while wandering about in Buckman neighborhood.

Interesting building stone from 1927 in Buckman.

Weird insignia in the tiles at the entrance of the building where I stayed. The building was built in the very early 1900s before swastika signs were associated with the Nazis.

Looking out from the entrance of the building where I stayed to Belmont Ave in Portland's East side.

Signs at Sizzle Pie in Buckman. Awesome pizza. And beer.

Blue skies and pouring rain. Only in the Pacific Northwest.

Downtown Portland from the Burnside Bridge.

A couple other Portland bridges viewed from the Burnside Bridge.

If you liked this post you should also check out my photos from San Diego.

entry.title: Eugene Pictures
entry.summary:
Eugene is a beautiful mix of eclectic, hipster, and quaint attributes. The downtown area offices house most of the tech companies. Eugene is branding itself "Silicon Shire" to distinguish it from its northern neighbor, "Silicon Forest" (Portland).

Wall art on the side of the Wandering Goat Coffee Company building (awesome place to hang out and work by the way).

More of the building wall art.

Interesting little musical instrument playing turtles.

The Barn Light coffee shop and bar. Awesome place to hang out.

Barcade!

Recent pinball machines...

...retro pinball machines! This place had an amazing selection of games to play (cheap too).

If you liked these pictures you should check out my photos from San Diego and Charlottesville.

entry.title: Computer History Museum in Mountain View, CA
entry.summary:
The Computer History Museum in Mountain View, California is an incredible walk through the computing timeline. The exhibits range from 17th century calculators to the iconic Cray Supercomputer featured in Jurassic Park.

Revolution. Current branding theme for the Computer History Museum.

Computing timeline 1950s to present.

Google's Maps car. I sat in it. It's no S2000.

A working model of Charles Babbage's Difference Engine.

Slide rules and very early calculators.

Handheld calculators from the 1970s.

Prototype 1949 precursor to today's magnetic hard drives.

Encryption and decryption device (Enigma machine) from Nazi Germany.

This old school commercial for the UNIVAC cracked me up. Nothing like 1950s advertising trying to explain computing to a mass audience years before personal computers (or even microcomputers) were invented.

The System/360 that still underpins billions of dollars in income for IBM. Also made famous in Fred Brooks' book The Mythical Man Month.

Timeline and influences in programming language history.

My current favorite programming language. Python. Dear God not Visual Basic.

Cray workers' gear.

A computer. In the kitchen. Imagine the possibilities! Complete commercial failure.

Sampling of Intel processors from the 1980s through the early 2000s. I remember building computers with almost all these chips (8088 was ahead of my time). I also skipped over the Pentium II for AMD's Athlon chips.

Early Pixar computer workstation.

My childhood in a museum.

Advertisements for very early "laptops."

Learn more about the Computer History Museum and take the time to visit next time you are in the Bay Area.

entry.title: Las Vegas Pictures
entry.summary:
I spent three nights in Las Vegas, Nevada from April 28 until May 1st. Most of my time was spent at Microconf 2013. I also checked out the Downtown Project and met a couple of fun girls from (where else other than) Austin, Texas, Carolina (@Carol91186) and Tabitha (@TabithaFierro) during the tour.

The original Las Vegas Strip sign downtown.

View of the highway while driving to Las Vegas from San Diego.

Las Vegas' interpretation of New York City.

The beginning of the tour for Downtown Project in Las Vegas. This is Tony Hseih's apartment which is part of the tour.

Sticky notes of ideas for Downtown Project.

View of downtown Las Vegas from Tony Hsieh's apartment.

All insane ideas start out as acts of insanity as well... how do we know beforehand which will turn out to be great?

A design sketch for one area being converted by the Downtown Project revitalization. Giant preying mantis included.

A view of the new Vegas Strip from Tony Hsieh's condo downtown.

Downtown Project scope as shown on an area map.

The original Las Vegas Strip.

Leaving Las Vegas.

If you liked this post you should check out my pictures from San Diego and Moab.

entry.title: San Diego Scenery
entry.summary:
The following are some initial pictures from San Diego to continue this theme after the overwhelmingly positive response to my Los Alamos and Moab pictures. I am in San Diego until Sunday so I'll probably have more pictures to post at some point.

Stopped to put the top down 70 miles outside San Diego.

View from Point Loma.

A view from Point Loma towards the downtown San Diego airport.

Statue at Point Loma overlooking the bay.

Walking around the streets San Diego. You can see the Padres' downtown stadium in the distance.

One of the downtown streets in San Diego that slopes down towards the water.

A shot from Balboa Park with the California Bell Tower and San Diego Museum of Man in the distance.

A few buildings on the edge of Balboa Park.

Flowers in Balboa Park.

Walking through Balboa Park.

Interesting trees in Balboa Park.

US Grant hotel viewed during the day. I stayed here for a few nights while downtown.

US Grant hotel at night.

Sunlight breaks through the clouds at Pacific Beach on the Bay side

Pacific Ocean view from Pacific Beach (PB) at dusk.

If you liked these pictures, check out Moab Scenery and Los Alamos is Beautiful.

entry.title: Moab Scenery
entry.summary:
I spent a couple of days in Moab, Utah over the weekend for mountain biking and camping. The contrast between the red rocks in Moab and the snow-capped mountains in the background was amazing. See these pictures below.

A snapshot of the drive through the mountains during the trip from Los Alamos to Moab.

Wilson Arch south of Moab.

Base jumping. Not me with the parachute there.

Memorial plaque for perished mountain bikers.

The S2000 looked a little out of place in Moab...

Home sweet... tent.

Mountains in the distance.

Sunset in Moab.

entry.title: Los Alamos is Beautiful
entry.summary:
I am spending a few days in Los Alamos, New Mexico and then Moab, Utah to catch my breath. It's beautiful here. Here are some photos I took during my drive up from Lubbock, Texas and while walking around town in Los Alamos.

The open road ahead. Insert metaphysical hand-wavy quote here about the winding road being an embodiment of my five month journey.

Same location shot from another angle. She's gettin' a little dirty.

The landscape shifts from completely flat in the Texas Panhandle to starting to have some hills. A little difficult to see in this shot.

Landscape shot while driving through the Texas Panhandle.

Landscape shot from out the side window in New Mexico.

A beautiful day...

...shifted suddenly into an eerie, ominous day. I thought I was going to find out if the S2000 still had the chops to outrun a tornado.

The terrain became noticeably different while in New Mexico. Flat land gave way to hills and mountainous areas in the distance.

After a little further on the drive the weather became beautiful again.

Just outside of Los Alamos I took my favorite shot of the trip so far.

Another shot of the amazing view.

Not pictured: steep drop into oblivion.

Good thing it wasn't icy on the way up or I might not be around to snap these shots.

This is a shot from today at Ashley Pond in Los Alamos.

Rock inscription at Ashley Pond in Los Alamos.

Nice mountain backdrop at Ashley Pond.

Asshole geese were being loud.

Native American ruins from 1225 in Los Alamos.

Dr. Oppenheimer immortalized in a bronze statue.

If you live around the Rocky Mountains, I hope you never get tired of this view or take it for granted. Amazing.

entry.title: Memphis Pictures
entry.summary:
Memphis was my fourth stop on my trip and one of the most memorable. My four day stay was highlighted by amazingly welcoming hosts, great food, live music, and an exciting whirlwind tour through the city.

BB King's Blues Club on Beale Street in Memphis, Tennessee.

Beale Street during the day...

...and at night.

Tiger mascot on University of Memphis campus where I gave a Memphis Python talk on Git/GitHub Workflows.

My favorite street graffiti I found in Memphis.

Main Street in Memphis. Locals prefer this to touristy Beale Street.

Sign on the River Walk in Memphis.

Nice houses overlooking the Mississippi River in Memphis.

Mississippi River Walk in Memphis.

Sign on the bridge from Memphis into Arkansas while leaving Memphis to drive down to Dallas, Texas.

If you liked these pictures you should check out my photos from Charlottesville, Virginia.

entry.title: Charlottesville, VA Pictures
entry.summary:
Here are a few "rear of the car"-perspective pictures from the first five days in Charlottesville. The first several pictures were taken during the full days I had in Charlottesville when I found an interesting place to pull over. The final picture was taken in Virginia on the way to Charlotte, North Carolina.

During my time in Charlottesville I met with Arin Sime of AgilityFeat and a group from WillowTree Apps. Posts on each company, as well as my thoughts on working in software development in Washington, DC versus Charlottesville coming soon.

Pulled over near Shenandoah Crossing Resort where I stayed during my time near Charlottesville.

Entrance to Horton Vineyard in Gordonsville, Virginia. Sadly I did not have time to stop and drink wine but I thought their buildings architecture was interesting.

The Rotunda at the University of Virginia, where I went to grad school for an MS in Management of Information Technology ('10). I wrote an in-depth six part blog series on the program a few months after I finished.

A sign marking the history of the area from the Revolutionary War.

A closer view of the sign.
